question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
True, because:

\(\lambda_2 \langle x_{1},x_2 \rangle\) \(= \langle x_1,\lambda_2 x_2 \rangle\) \(= \langle x_1,A x_2 \rangle\) \(= \langle A^* x_1,x_2 \rangle\) \(= \langle A x_1,x_2 \rangle\)

Because the matrix is hermitian

\(= \langle \lambda_1 x_1,x_2 \rangle\) \(= \overline{\lambda_1} \langle x_1,x_2 \rangle\) \(= \lambda_1 \langle x_1,x_2 \rangle\)

Because hermitian matrices have real eigenvalues. So

\(\lambda_1 \langle x_1,x_2 \rangle = \lambda_2 \langle x_1,x_2 \rangle\).

Given that \(\lambda_1 \neq \lambda_2\), this can only be true if \(\langle x_1,x_2 \rangle = 0\)
